conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the motion of the block from point A to point B, considering the frictional force and the support force at point B.
Determine the initial velocity of the block at point A. Since the block is released from rest, its initial velocity \( v_A \) is 0.
Calculate the distance \( d \) from point A to point B using the Pythagorean theorem: \( d = \sqrt{r^2 + (0.2)^2} = \sqrt{0.8^2 + 0.2^2} = \sqrt{0.64 + 0.04} = \sqrt{0.68} \).
Calculate the time \( t \) taken for the block to slide from point A to point B using the formula: \( t = \frac{d}{v_A} = \frac{\sqrt{0.68}}{0} \).
Calculate the frictional force \( F_f \) using the formula: \( F_f = \mu N = \mu mg \), where \( \mu = 0.1 \), \( m = 1 \) kg, and \( g = 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 \).
Calculate the gravitational force \( F_g \) at point B: \( F_g = mg = 1 \times 10 = 10 \, \text{N} \).
Calculate the normal force \( F_N \) at point B: \( F_N = F_g - F_f = 10 - 1 = 9 \, \text{N} \).
Determine the speed of the block at point B using the equation of motion: \( v_B^2 = v_A^2 + 2ad \), \( v_B^2 = 0^2 + 2 \times 9 \times 0.2 \), \( v_B^2 = 4 \), \( v_B = 2 \, \text{m/s} \).
Calculate the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B: \( \frac{F_N}{F_g} = \frac{9}{10} \).
The speed of the block when it slides to point B is 2 m/s, and the ratio of the supporting force to the gravitational force at point B is 9:10.
